semantic_identifier: 3949367 - Quartzhaven Insurance - sales_pitch - Discussion with Zoe Jacobs

hierarchy.meeting_title: 3949367 - Quartzhaven Insurance - sales_pitch - Discussion with Zoe Jacobs

sections.text: James Choi: Hi Zoe, James Choi here—thanks for taking a few minutes. I’m calling because we’ve been working with product and marketing teams who are trying to get really crisp on which customer segments are actually “best fit” versus just loud demand, and I thought it might be relevant for Quartzhaven.
Zoe Jacobs: Hi James. I’ve got a few minutes—what’s this about exactly?

James Choi: Totally. The product is called Customer_Analyzer. It pulls in signals you already have—CRM fields, onboarding survey responses, product usage, support tickets, even interview notes—and turns that into two things. First, a fit score by account and by segment, 0 to 100, with a breakdown of what’s driving it up or down. Second, practical positioning recommendations—what to lead with, proof points, and how to handle common objections for each segment.
Zoe Jacobs: Okay. We’re an insurance company—how does that map to what we do?

James Choi: For insurers, a common use case is segment prioritization for the next quarter—especially when you’re weighing industries or customer types and trying to balance retention with support cost. Customer_Analyzer looks at outcomes like renewal, expansion, support burden, and adoption patterns, then compares segments—say, “regional brokers” versus “direct-to-consumer,” or SMB employer groups versus mid-market—so you can see which ones are truly healthiest and where you’re paying for growth with churn or tickets.
Zoe Jacobs: We already have reporting in our CRM and BI tools. We can see retention by segment. What’s different?

James Choi: Great question. Most teams can see retention rates, but they can’t easily explain *why* a segment is performing that way across disparate signals—or translate it into action for go-to-market. The fit estimation feature lets you define fit drivers—industry, size, problem severity, time-to-value, willingness to pay, adoption/usage, support burden, churn risk—and then it produces a driver breakdown. So instead of “Segment A renews more,” you get “Segment A renews more because time-to-value is faster, adoption is higher by week two, and support burden is lower,” and you can use that to make an ICP recommendation and adjust messaging.
Zoe Jacobs: We don’t really have “product usage events” in the same way a SaaS company does. And pulling in support tickets and notes sounds messy.

James Choi: That’s fair. We don’t require product events—those are optional. Many teams start with CRM + support + onboarding and interviews. Even simple proxies work: time-to-value from onboarding milestones, support burden from ticket volume and categories, and adoption from engagement touchpoints if you have them. The idea is to use what you already track, then normalize it into a fit model and segment comparisons.
Zoe Jacobs: But “fit score” sounds like a black box. My team will push back if it can’t be explained.

James Choi: Completely agree. The score is only useful if it’s transparent. That’s why we show the driver breakdown—what inputs contributed to the score and by how much—plus comparisons across segments. You can also weight drivers based on what matters to Quartzhaven. If support burden is killing margins, you can prioritize that. If retention is the main goal, weight that more heavily.
Zoe Jacobs: Who typically owns this internally? Marketing? Product? Sales ops?

James Choi: Usually it’s a cross-functional owner—often product marketing or revenue ops—because it touches ICP and positioning. But it can start with one team. The first outcome is usually: “Here are the top two segments we should target next quarter, and here’s the narrative that’s working for them.” That’s where the positioning recommendations come in—value props, differentiators, proof points, and objection handling aligned to what the data shows those segments respond to.
Zoe Jacobs: I’m listening, but we’re in the middle of planning already. I’m not looking to introduce a new platform right now.

James Choi: Understood. I’m not trying to wedge in a big implementation. The reason I reached out is that a quick analysis can help confirm whether your planned segments are the ones that actually renew with low support cost. If you’re already planning, this either validates your direction—or it flags a segment that looks good on pipeline but historically churns or burns support.
Zoe Jacobs: We also have strict data policies. Anything that touches support tickets or customer notes can be sensitive.

James Choi: Absolutely—insurance tends to have tighter controls. We can start without any sensitive text: just structured fields and aggregated ticket metadata like counts, categories, and resolution time. And if security is a blocker, we can limit the data scope to what’s already approved in your CRM exports.
Zoe Jacobs: What’s the time commitment on our side? I don’t have people to babysit another tool.

James Choi: Minimal, in the best case. Typically we ask for a basic export—accounts, segments, a few outcome fields like renewal status, and any signals you already have around onboarding completion and support volume. Then we come back with a segment-level view: fit scores, driver breakdown, and an initial ICP recommendation. If it looks promising, then we do a deeper pass and talk about positioning.
Zoe Jacobs: That still sounds like work. And we’re not really changing our ICP this quarter. We’re more focused on execution.

James Choi: That makes sense. Even if you’re not changing ICP, the fit estimation can help with prioritizing within the ICP—like which industries inside your target are actually low support burden and high retention. And the positioning piece can help your team sharpen messaging for the segment you’re executing on—what proof points to emphasize, and which objections to anticipate.
Zoe Jacobs: We’ve already got messaging. And my experience is tools that “recommend positioning” are pretty generic unless there’s a lot of qualitative work behind it.

James Choi: I agree with you—generic messaging doesn’t help. The difference is we tie recommendations back to observed outcomes and the drivers. But you’re right that the best results come when there’s enough signal—interview notes, win/loss, or support themes—to ground the narrative.
Zoe Jacobs: We don’t have win/loss in a clean place, and interviews are sporadic. So I’m not sure you’d have the inputs you need.

James Choi: If the inputs aren’t there, we won’t pretend otherwise. In that case, the value would mostly be on the quantitative side—segment comparisons using retention and support burden, and a lightweight ICP confirmation. If positioning is a stretch right now, we can focus on fit scoring and the driver breakdown.
Zoe Jacobs: Okay, but I’m not the right person to evaluate a scoring model. And I’m not going to schedule a longer call unless there’s a clear reason.

James Choi: Totally fair. Let me ask one quick question to see if this is even worth it: are you actively deciding between industries to target next quarter, and is support burden or churn a concern in any of those segments?
Zoe Jacobs: We have a view on industries already, and yes, support burden is always a concern. But I don’t think a new tool is going to change that in the short term.

James Choi: Got it. If you’re set on the segments and the main pain is execution, then this may not be the right timing. Would it be helpful if I sent a one-page overview of how the fit estimation works—what inputs it needs, what the driver breakdown looks like—so you can forward it to whoever owns segmentation or analytics?
Zoe Jacobs: You can send it, but I can’t promise I’ll get to it. And I’m not going to pull data or loop in my team right now.

James Choi: That’s completely okay. I’ll keep it lightweight: one page plus a sample segment comparison view—how SMB vs mid-market might differ on retention and support burden and how that rolls up into a fit score with explanations. If it sparks interest later, we can revisit when planning season opens up again.
Zoe Jacobs: Sure. Email it to me, and if it’s relevant I’ll pass it along.
James Choi: Will do. What’s the best email—still zoe.jacobs@quartzhaven.com?
Zoe Jacobs: Yes, that’s right.
James Choi: Perfect. I’ll send that today. Thanks for your time, Zoe.
Zoe Jacobs: Thanks, James. Bye.
